poem0: the problem with unseen disability is that many people cannot see it and often do not believe you have it the problem with an unseen disability is you feel it on the inside and it does not show on the outside the problem with an unseen disability is it may be mental disorders emotional disorders eating disorders etc and unless your family or someone close to you knows of the problem people will just brush you off as being lazy the problem with an unseen disability is it is hard for the person dealing with them to live everyday life just as it is for people with seeing physical limitations so please do not judge unless you know the facts about the person standing in front of you
poem1: pride is the rust of sunshine rays of hope corrupted by its way love is murdered by its claim light of beauty drowning in dismay shadows curse slowly infiltrates
poem2: am making list tonight of all the things wanted to say but did not the list goes little something like this you stop talking you your problems do not affect anyone or anything in the slightest me should have told you there and then write it all down in neat hand in the hopes that one day someone will open the list and be able to realize exactly what meant to say the other day when told you “do not worry it will get better am afraid that one day will wake up and throw the list away or one day would just shove it in your face tired of hoping waiting for an apology somehow am still sitting here making list tonight of all the things wanted to say but will never say anyway
poem3: nine thousand years seems long but for the imagination see siberian girl smile as she reaches out to touch the saggital crest shaped like an arrow indicating strong jaw muscles on the head of husky once removed from wolf panting by the fire after pulling home sled of reindeer meat now see them both die you can fill in the because buried in single grave discovered just last year time anglo saxon timma tide streams through us modifying species and individuals little by little at birth our innocent lungs fill with air with time sails catching breeze seedlings thrusting up watery green stems rushing through the detritus of april pushing up thickening billowing until the instant the fatal blossom explodes at the tip time is older than the oldest language its silence older than its creatures’ utterances attempted expressions of their lives it travels through some bodies faster than others leaving behind sloughed shapes unfinished shadows it has moved through each of my three dogs seven times faster than through me ii two hundred years of selective breeding have spawned monstrous array of creatures called “dogs becoming ever fitter for human purposes including friendliness and laboratory testing eighty four percent of our dna is the same sixteen percent remains unknown useless to the other wild guns are quick to put down useless animals this morning see man whip large scottish terrier bred to rid farms of vermin and to help seize game with the leash he carries the giant dog refuses to heel stare hard at the man’s back my limbic brain shooting fight then flight then powerlessness then from my newer frontal lobe hope he will eventually change he calls to mind my father fifty years ago whipping his brittany spaniel bred in france as gun dogs when often in memory scream at him to stop he always drops the rolled up newspaper ever surprised iii my last dog is mix of husky sled pullers guards hunters and german shepherd search and rescue police and military thirteen years seems long except for the imagination my children grown find myself before the cages at the shelter just to look they say am too old for the adolescent handsome male have chosen categorized on his cage as “orange” meaning he needs lots of exercise incensed at their assessment of me pay the fee to take last dog home and though they are correct in that cannot run as fast as he they do not know that he will come to lope beside my bike the two of us pulled by instinct and imagination team in the iditarod at 62 believe last dog and might live out our lives concurrently at 75 it does not seem so likely iv time is stealthy anglo saxon stehlen to steal eight thousand years seems long but for the imagination hear lao tzu speak time makes possible all that is what allows us to live permits us to die walt whitman insists mere 150 years gone death is different from what any one supposes and luckier am counting on luck composing detailed script for when time is nearly through with me but pain is not if can catch that sweet spot will not eat or drink this is called suicide though if someone withholds nourishment at my behest it is termed murder to rub away harm both are sins synne of unknown origin dogs may be bred for aggression but they never hold their breath imagining death they do not anticipate we do in liver sausage he never refuses hide antibiotics for the sepsis that leaves last dog trembling feverish after each chemo treatment the palliative prednisone makes him manic knocking coasters off the coffee table with his nose in replay of his puppyhood never saw am patient cook meals twice day and he eats voraciously pisses constantly he is anxious panting for something am not ready to give never bred for displays of affection now he pushes his head into my lap relentlessly asking asking it is just question of time restoring last dog me or in fact the earth that together we have explored to health is out of the question compose another script will hire his murderer rely on stranger with her needle of oblivion to force time to unleash last dog’s body as painlessly as possible leaving me for we will of course have separate graves for time still alive attended by his completed shadow this leaves the heavy grief grever to weigh down afflict that all of us must carry in proportion to our given length of life breadth of vision depth of what else to call it love
poem4: yulan magnolias blossom first as birds little feathered fists admit to imagining could harm me extending barefaced from trees the known homes of jinn am told the night deepens and locusts halo my head or do not believe me barely believe the heralds have seen the mirror windowed if stare beat too long my face refracting others foremothers my beloved’s hands rising in supplication under winter rain stopping after spotting the dead sparrow by the door bent like comma— as if asking him to pause or telling me to wait
poem5: heard them wings beating din beyond the thistle pilgrims beckoned by the promise of carrion lured by the lurid followed their song off the path turned my back to the lake angels fled the quarry thirst blight in their wake the flies their mouths roved like dogs the breast of sundered wren chest wide as lens steady spectator of its own death this is an economy of asylum ruddy flesh calls come and brutes abound haloing their open handed new home am divining my body dirtied domestic when it rains devotion is the womb have hollowed to keep desire dry
poem6: when put the small cobalt vase into the shopping basket he tells me had donated that same vase to that same goodwill months ago mocking me only little for not remembering last night watched him put halved plums on baking dish shake brown sugar and fresh thyme over them add bit of water and roast them until they sank into soft sweetness few weeks ago talked to my mother about the different kinds of portable urinals she might buy to use during her recovery our grief and mirth at the one that looked like garbage bag you slipped onto yourself there was the long moment too when stood before the linden tree by the parking lot on campus asking it what it had seen during the year everyone disappeared like tree thriving inside ruined roofless cathedral this summer we sat outside and talked about those who had died he had been bank manager and stole money and left the country she had had an affair with priest the afternoon like gossip turning into legend got dark in the winter in my dreams people would appear their complexions dry and gray as mushrooms they asked for directions or stood at the wall while did some task that would never be finished did not know these people but understood they knew me like ghosts like ancestors their old desires thick in our new desires it is not that had forgotten giving it away it is that wanted the blue vase back having lost it that once this morning watched him lie in bed without clothes and knew the pungence of every fold of his body the way your fingers smell after rubbing some thyme sprinkler was on outside sound like jump rope on the sidewalk then the sound of children the neighbor’s children leading me to that ladder within the self with the boy on low rung the man on the middle rungs and the old man above us touching the leaves of the tree
poem7: anywhere anyone men boys—but women too and children babies unborn in the womb doctors dispensing every kind of diagnosis fear fueling rumors as the flowers germinate and spread voracious purple hemlock inching trunk to collarbone jaw to ear to eye kisses sicken loving any body but your own may kill semen needles saliva breast milk— on and on the list unfurls dread epitaph proclaiming queer rail against the fleeing gods spit into the wind you will tire soon enough the worst is always unimaginable though you knew well before the verdict dropped— weakness fever chills those greedy rated blooms now you tell me what is zero hour with no one left to count
poem8: standing unseen in the little bluestem curious and not quite used to living consider whether it is aliens that brought black folks to the canyons valley standing in the great evaporation of lake holy dandelion for eyes full and white and searching the landscape for understanding how do you come to be where there are no others except science fiction am child feeling extraterrestrial whose history untold is not enough anyway it begins with abduction
poem9: my mother had the power that knowledge wields so questions such as—would you like to go were never invitations but commands to fly away cross yellow fields and low like summer insects stuck upon windshields raggle taggle group we were and so like sandflies could not change what time demands beneath half known psychic undertow my mother screeched her well worn wearing wheels as we pulled up to watch the wild geese soar in ordered honking triangles much more we would missed such ordered symmetry before
poem10: am making list tonight of all the things wanted to say but did not the list goes little something like this you stop talking you your problems do not affect anyone or anything in the slightest me should have told you there and then write it all down in neat hand in the hopes that one day someone will open the list and be able to realize exactly what meant to say the other day when told you “do not worry it will get better am afraid that one day will wake up and throw the list away or one day would just shove it in your face tired of hoping waiting for an apology somehow am still sitting here making list tonight of all the things wanted to say but will never say anyway
poem11: in this unveiling rain stabbed blackbird’s obsidian sigh rises from meat fragrant slits in our speech patterns where way of seeing home smeared on walls with elbow blood is also way of nozzling bird caw to thieved land or scissoring fog lobed night into crescent moons while bell’s deoxygenated moan weeping for its lost reflection is hauled away on horse drawn hearse
poem12_title: IN MY NEXT LIFE LET ME BE A TOMATO
poem12: another failed chance to vault froglike into new life it is pre green thinned acrylic approximating watercolor and with paintbrush am pollinating lemon trees impersonating bees still so far from honeyed could not kill stinkbug but somehow it was easy to betray you ants swarmed the semen damp cloth releasing their glossy bodies into moss allowed myself to pretend am not monstrous every year this ritual spring is only performance of reinvention the flowers keep becoming themselves always the stinkbug concealed behind its shield the hungry horny ants the sparrow undoing her nest as pull apart my life have to believe azalea buds might swoon into forsythia while nearby snow melts to milk some proof could become improbably gentle good as drops of water on turned dirt
poem13: if the ghost of zora neale hurston could haunt poetry collection it would be gumbo ya ya which won the cave canem poetry prize in 2020 obvious homage is paid to hurston especially mules and men with the raucous chatter of black voices and folklore bursting from marie’s poems placed firmly in the deep south and all its dangers glories and inherent contradictions for queer black femme who must navigate the choppy waters of racism and patriarchy while so full of love for her people that can so often lead to an even deeper grief as this country steals their lives but this collection is like hurston herself loud audacious celebration of black people no matter who is looking
